and co tts seen all have Abbey Junction for the station concerned. OS maps show as effectively one station.

[private line south of West Ham] (non-tt): visit of interested Vestries to this addition to London’s sewage disposal system on opening 30 July 1868 and whole week following; by river to North Woolwich and rail to West Ham, then private line
(Shipping & Mercantile Gazette 30 July; Kentish Independent August 8).
[GNS] (non-tt): pilgrimages; train for Roman Catholic pilgrimage to ‘special platform’ 9 square feet on down side near bridge 701, 100 yards east of milepost 32½
Aberdeen Press ... where always day after date given for event
, though some had always come that way
[SE] op on or by 1 November 1849 (included in notice of alterations
, but not in earlier notices seen); still open.
Earliest co tt for line has place for this occupied by HARROW ROAD, no trains calling – intended name? (D Banks); at first one word in

[MC]: Macaulay’s 1851 map shows station just west of Leegate; not on 1854 map. No supporting evidence for existence. See 1840** for habits of MC; perhaps site between stations at which trains called often enough to cause confusion for someone drafting maps at a distance; perhaps stop for people of Abbey and district – seems to have disappeared from Macaulay’s maps at about time the North British opened its station there and latter was shown as ABBEY HOLM on his maps, early 1860s at least.
, but that a Sunday, no Sunday service here – first in
as WORCESTER J; renamed 1 March 1852 co tt
; exchange only but in public tt; clo 1 October 1855
(non-tt): stops for staff shown 17 June 1957 wtt; {Folkestone East – Dover}.
May 1856 – line op 5 April 1856 but A F not in op notice
, paper of 3 May (next issue) said passengers now booked to ‘BOLDSIDE (A.F.)’; clo 5 January 1931
of this name probably op 5 April 1847 (in co tt of that date,
, assumed to be opening tt as far as this station was concerned); although in tt, more of a private station for Crawshay Bailey than a public one; last train ran 12 July 1856 (Saturday)
, TREAMAN, op nearby October 1848; re-sited about ¾ mile north January 1857; renamed A 1888/9 – authorised 26 October 1888

to 1854 but still thus Monmouthshire co wtt November 1865.
[High; NB] op 22 July 1903**; clo 1 November 1911 (Wednesday), reop 1 August 1913
as DUFFRYN CROSSING PLATFORM; became A PLATFORM 1906 tt
; see 1904** for other name changes; first in
[TV] op 8 October 1840** as NAVIGATION HOUSE; became ABERDARE JUNCTION 1849 tt
In 2008 the junction between Aberdare and Merthyr lines was re-sited and one enlarged station replaced the two previous. Last train used
Saturday 24 May 2008 but station not officially closed until 30 May, because of time needed to complete the work, and then
; just north of main station, at / near later Abercynon North; op 6 August 1846; order to move it south alongside TV station given 23 March 1848; merged with TV
Both ABERDARE JUNCTION stations reduced to exchange only after 29 October 1855 owing to dispute with landlord of nearby public house; full service again 1 May 1856
; old HL reop. Previously used for shoppers’ specials Saturdays 1 and 15 December 1984
; again 19 January, 16 February, 16 March and in September 1985
Also see COMMERCIAL STREET; MILL STREET.
Line from south op to temporary terminus at
References assumed to relate to same site, but this not certain – different distances result of re-siting or press guesswork? C
onnecting line joins Scot NE at ticket platform
x-Empress Eugenie (widow of Napoleon III) arrived from Perth at ticket platform about 1,000 yards outside station; her saloon switched to Ballater train outside station
esterday train from Banchory halted at ticket platform 500 yards from station owing to snow
– Queen to spend 5 minutes at ticket platform at
icket platform opposite Dee Village; spectators in Wellington Road cheered Gladstone
Marquess of Salisbury (Prime Minister) served with breakfast at Ferryhill ticket platform when on way to Balmoral.
. Earlier terminus kept for this purpose?
eparate structure or station used as collection point
timing cited in connection with accelerated service
Wales’s saloon taken off ordinary train at Schoolhill ticket platform and then on by special train to Ballater
At north end of Duthie Park for departure of Princess Beartice after opening Park 27 September 1883
For ordinary passengers, visit of Prince and Princes of Wales, for whom exclusive use of station was reserved, 28 April 1884
For presentation of a loyal address to Shah of Persia at Ferryhill Junction on his way back from visit to Deeside 18 June 1889
– paper cited did not mention platform but others that did, including
, called it Ferryhead Junction. Possible this site was also used to present loyal addresses to Queen Victoria. Was this same as ticket platform?

One for visit of Tsar Nicholas II 22 September 1897 at Ferryhill Junction for him to have tea and be switched to line for Ballater; this one had to be removed promptly to allow ordinary traffic to resume, so not exactly same as others
In area known as east docks (previously used as shunting yard) for excursion traffic; first used 5 July 1902 and later for Highland and Agricultural Show (15-18 July, inclusive)

: Savin, builder and early operator of line, used siding from 21 chains west of Ynyslas to Cerrig y Penrhyn, opposite harbour to ferry passengers and building materials across (shown, in truncated form, as FERRY in Col Cobb’s Atlas); no station or BoT sanction; this service ran until line along north bank of River Dovey supposed to open. Faulty tunnels led to BoT refusal for their use but rest of line and new station op 14 August 1867
, passengers being at first taken round faulty stretch by road
– footnote to advertisement of excursion trains
said arrangement was temporary, worked out with landowners (presumably while disputes settled); still open. 1877

July 1884; HALT added 1 May 1956, dropped 6 May 1968

ng) op 22 December 1902** (see for details); transferred to preservation 1989.
; became A MONMOUTH ROAD 19 July 1950, reverted 6 May 1968 tt
LNW] existed to provide link between Hereford to Newport line, already open, and Abergavenny to Tredegar line, op 1 October 1862; opening tt
showed A BRECON ROAD as eastern terminus of latter; existence taken for granted, intended only as exchange, since
said through booking to main line was possible, thus absence from public tt; first in
March 1864, then only in GW tables; added to LNW later. Re-sited 25 chains north 20 June 1870
. In LNW co tt 1864-70, at least: MERTHYR, TREDEGAR & A J.
and 1888/9 on; LNW co tt 1869/70 to 1870/74 and 1874/5 on.
as NANTMOR for ABERGLASLYN; see 1922 July 31**; renamed 9 July 1934
